awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms-A (CSDM-A) program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Irving R. Epstein and his research group at Brandeis University are studying the properties of chemical reactions that are far from equilibrium.  Chemical equilibrium is a condition where a chemical reaction has not ceased, but the forward reaction to produce products and the backward reactions to produce reactants balance each other such that the concentration of reactants and products do not change.  Chemical reactions that have not achieved equilibrium shift to reach this condition, and interesting things can result in the process.  The Epstein group is conducting experiments wherein complex three-dimensional patterns of chemicals form in solution.  Epstein is also developing theoretical models to explain the emergence and evolution of these structures.  Such work may provide insights into how structures form in biological systems.  The research group is also employing 3D printing technologies to study patterns on three-dimensional surfaces.  They investigate patterns that grow on expanding domains, analogous to the situation in developing embryos and organisms.  Finally, the Epstein group is also investigating how chemical reactions may be used to drive the motion of certain materials, a concept that could lead to primitive "soft robots." The post-doctoral and graduate student researchers involved in this project are gaining experience in experimental laboratory techniques and computer simulation of complex chemical reactions.  In addition to the training and professional development, the educational impacts of the project include continued work by Professor Epstein and his students to incorporate nonlinear chemical dynamics into the undergraduate curriculum.  They also conduct STEM outreach to underrepresented minorities and generally disadvantaged communities via the Brandeis Science Posse, a program founded by Epstein.

This project explores macroscopic pattern formation originating in reaction-diffusion and related processes involving oscillating chemical reactions.  The chemical systems include the Belousov-Zhabotinsky reaction (BZ), the chlorite-iodide-malonic acid (CIMA) system, and the chlorine dioxide-iodine-malonic acid (CDIMA).  The Epstein group is engaging five general areas of investigation: the characterization turing patterns formed in three dimensions, pattern formation in growing domains; patterns arising from differential growth (as opposed to simple reaction-diffusion); coupled oscillators, and locomotion and chemo-mechanical transduction in BZ-gel systems.  All experimental work is supported by model simulations.  In addition to the training and professional development of a post-doctoral fellow and a graduate student, the educational impacts of the project include continued work by Professor Epstein and his students to incorporate nonlinear chemical dynamics into the undergraduate curriculum.  They also conduct STEM outreach to underrepresented minorities and generally disadvantaged communities via the Brandeis Science Posse, a program founded by Epstein.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project was devoted to the experimental, theoretical and computational study of nonlinear chemical dynamics, the behavior in time and space of complex chemical systems undergoing reaction and diffusion. 

Many of our accomplishments during this reporting period involved the experimental and computational study of Turing patterns, the temporally stationary, spatially periodic patterns first proposed by Alan Turing as a possible mechanism for morphogenesis in living systems.  We developed a model involving interaction between several types of pigmented cells for the development of patterns on the skin of the zebrafish.  An example of our results is shown in Figure 1. We constructed an experimental protocol for studying Turing patterns on growing domains, mimicking the situation in developing organisms, by exploiting the photosensitivity of the chlorine dioxide-iodine-malonic acid (CDIMA) reaction.  We used this technique to demonstrate experimentally that, as predicted by mathematicians, the rate of growth influences the structure of the final pattern, and we successfully simulated the results with the Lengyel-Epstein model.  We then expanded these studies to include the effects of inert obstacles on the growth of Turing patterns.  Some results are shown in Figure 2.  Finally, we wrote an invited review on insights from chemical systems into morphogenesis for a journal issue focusing on Turing?s work.

A second area of focus has been the analytical and numerical study of coupled oscillators, which may serve as models for the interaction between cells, e.g., neurons, in living organisms.  Using the Lengyel-Epstein model of the CDIMA reaction, we identified and analyzed novel forms of behavior when two identical oscillators are coupled by diffusion.  We found novel scenarios in which one oscillator undergoes simple periodic large amplitude oscillation while the other exhibits small amplitude complex behavior, such as chaos. We also discovered a new route to chaos in a system of coupled van der Pol oscillators, which have been used to model oscillations in electrical circuits.  In collaboration with a pair of applied mathematicians, we developed an approach to understanding the behavior of coupled oscillators that contain a fast and a slow variable based on the occurrence of special points called folded singularities.  We used this technique to identify a variety of previously unseen temporal patterns in both the Lengyel-Epstein and the van der Pol models.  This "Cartesian Product Quilt" approach, illustrated in Figure 3, offers promise for understanding complex dynamical behavior in a wide range of coupled oscillator systems.

We carried out several investigations of chemomechanical transduction, the transformation of the energy stored in chemical bonds into mechanical energy that can produce motion, in the Belousov-Zhabotinsky (BZ) reaction in gels.  Waves of chemical reaction result in motion of the gels, analogous to the process that occurs in muscle.  We first established the dependence of the wavelength of pulse waves in the system on reactant concentrations and temperature, with the aim of identifying conditions for sub-millimeter waves that would be ideal for molecular motors.  We showed how spiral waves can be used to control the transition between different motion modes of a square gel patch and how internal chemical signals can lead to rotational locomotion of such a patch, suggesting a mechanism for organisms to exhibit such motion even in the absence of appendages like legs or fins.  We then examined the collective behavior of groups of gel patches, focusing on the role of heterogeneity among the members of the group.  We found that the existence and location of a few "leaders" can control the behavior of the group, including transitions from irregular, random motion to ordered periodic circular or swing-forward motion.  The results suggest approaches to designing the behavior of, for example, robot swarms.  An example is shown in Figure 4.

Broader Impacts include the development of demonstrations, suitable for either classroom or laboratory use, of sequential spatiotemporal patterns in the Briggs-Rauscher reaction and of Turing patterns in the CDIMA reaction.  The former work has been published in the Journal of Chemical Education, and the latter study has been submitted for publication in that journal.  Some of the research in this project served as a source of material for a course on dynamical systems taught by the PI, who also developed and supported two cohort-based programs aimed at increasing the retention of underrepresented students in STEM. He collaborated with colleagues at Hampton University, an HBCU, to create a program, including a summer research internship at Brandeis, that will bring nine Hampton undergraduates to enroll in STEM masters programs at Brandeis this fall.
